newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish coalition leaders set for crisis talks.
newsitem.headline: Turkish coalition leaders set for crisis talks.

text.p: The leaders of Turkey's crumbling Islamist-led government met their party elders ahead of talks on Sunday on ways to resolve the deepening crisis surrounding their coalition.

Advisers to Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan and his secularist deputy, Tansu Ciller, said the two were to meet in the afternoon ahead of a news conference expected to set out the future of their 11-month-old alliance.
"It is not clear when the two are meeting, but a news conference is set for four o'clock (1300 GMT) at the prime minister's office," a spokesman for Erbakan told Reuters.
The Turkish press said the two leaders would discuss a government reshuffle and early elections.
Meanwhile, a leading member of Erbakan's Islam-based Welfare Party told a news conference that early polls were needed.
"Early elections have become a necessity...Delaying elections would be risky for our democracy," Welfare deputy leader Riza Ulucak told reporters at party headquarters.

A minister from Ciller's True Path Party (DYP) said on Saturday elections could be held as early as October to end the crisis in the coalition since the military demanded a crackdown on Islamist activism.
"We do not know the certain date but elections could take place in mid-October," state-run Anatolian news agency quoted Health Minister Ismail Karakuyu as saying.
The DYP has been locked in bargaining with its Islamist coalition partners over a possible date for early elections to save the coalition.
Ciller promised her party she would press Erbakan, modern Turkey's first Islamist leader, to let her lead the country to polls as caretaker head of government.

However, the two sides have been unable to agree on a date. Turkish press reports say Erbakan wants a quick poll, but Ciller was holding out for a date next spring. Elections would normally be due by the year 2000.
Under the existing coalition protocol, Ciller was to take over the prime minister's office in June of 1998.
Erbakan met for four hours on Saturday evening with leading members of his Welfare Party after a monthly meeting of the National Security Council (NSC), state-run Anatolian news agency reported.
At the NSC meeting, the secularist armed forces renewed pressure on Erbakan to curb a rise in Moslem activism since he became prime minister last June.

Erbakan has dragged his feet, setting him at odds with Ciller's conservative and secularist party members. That has caused a steady flow of defections of True Path MPs and ministers decrying Erbakan's failure to implement the army directives.
On Friday the resignation of a senior True Path deputy and former minister cost the government its absolute majority in parliament, leaving it one seat short of the 276 votes needed.
